Fig 8 Transition metal atom doped Ni3S2 as efficient bifunctional electrocatalysts for overall water splitting: Design strategy from DFT studies Yibo Chen a Xinyu Zhang a ⁎ Jiaqian Qin b Riping Liu a a State Key Laboratory of Metastable Materials Science and Technology, Yanshan University, Qinhuangdao 066004, Hebei, China State Key Laboratory of Metastable Materials Science and Technology, Yanshan University Qinhuangdao Hebei 066004 China aState Key Laboratory of Metastable Materials Science and Technology, Yanshan University, Qinhuangdao 066004, Hebei, China b Metallurgy and Materials Science Research Institute, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok 10330, Thailand Metallurgy and Materials Science Research Institute, Chulalongkorn University Bangkok 10330 Thailand bMetallurgy and Materials Science Research Institute, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok 10330, Thailand ⁎ Corresponding author. Exploring stable, inexpensive and highly active bifunctional electrocatalyst for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a long-desired topic in the area of sustainable and renewable energy sources. Herein, ten kinds of transition metal (TM = Mn, Fe, Co, Cu, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir and Pt) were doped in Ni3S2 matrix to design TM-Ni3S2 candidates, and their catalytic activities for overall water splitting were systematically explored based on density functional theory. Our results demonstrated that doping TM atoms is an effective tactic to boost the catalytic activity of Ni3S2 matrix. Among these candidates, Mn-Ni3S2, Fe-Ni3S2, and Ru-Ni3S2 exhibit the outstanding catalytic activity for water splitting, with the much lower overpotentials being just 0.02/0.29 V, 0.11/0.29 V and 0.01/0.33 V for HER/OER, respectively, which are equivalent to or even superior to the prevailing bifunctional catalysts. Particularly, d-band center was employed to reveal the origin of OER activity. Our findings may open up new routes for the design of advanced Ni3S2-based catalysts for water splitting and realize the wide-range applications of Ni3S2-based catalysts in fields of clean and renewable energy. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ni3S2 Overall water splitting Bifunctional electrocatalysts DFT study Introduction The overuse of fossil fuels, the aggravation of energy crisis as well as the deterioration of ecological environment have compelled us to explore the green renewable energy conversion and storage technologies, such as electricity-driven water splitting [1], metal-air battery [2], nitrogen reduction [3], etc. Among these clean and sustainable energy technologies, water-splitting reaction is driven by cathodic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER), which is identified as an outstanding strategy for producing next-generation renewable energy carrier, hydrogen. However, owing to the slow kinetics for these two reactions, the key to electrochemical water splitting is designing the highly efficient electrocatalysts to reduce reaction overpotentials for electrochemical reaction. Currently, the noble metal based-materials, such as Pt, IrO2 and RuO2, are regarded as the superior electrocatalysts for HER [4]and OER [5, 6], respectively. Nevertheless, the large-scale commercial applications are confined by their inadequacy and prohibitive cost. Regarding unifunctional catalysts, the catalytic activity of two separate unifunctional catalysts is generally poor than that of bifunctional catalysts because of different optimal operating conditions [7]. Meanwhile, the mass usage of materials and optimization procedures lead to a high production cost. Hence, achieving stable, affordable, durable and highly efficient bifunctional catalysts for overall water splitting, is a long-standing challenging yet appealing problem to solve. Up to now, continuous efforts have been devoted to explore a variety of inexpensive catalysts as the promising alternatives to noble-metal catalysts, including transitional metal sulfides [8, 9], carbides [10–12], oxides [13, 14]and phosphides [15–17]. Among these alternatives, transitional metal sulfides, especially including the earth-abundant metal elements [18–20] (e.g., Fe, Co, Ni), have received extensive attentions as a promising catalyst for water splitting. For example, Ni3S2, possessing a continuous network of Ni-Ni bonds, has been demonstrated to be potential catalysts for water splitting owing to its high conductivity. However, the intrinsic activity of Ni3S2 is still inferior to the benchmark noble-metal catalysts. So far, various modification strategies, including heteroatom doping [21, 22], hetero-interface coupling [23, 24], have been extensively devoted to tune the electronic structure of Ni3S2 to improve its catalytic activity. Among these, as an extremely effective method, heteroatom doping [25, 26] has been widely used to increase reactive sites and reduce reaction energy barrier for HER or OER. For example, Kou et al. [27] reported that introducing N modification can significantly enhance the catalytic activity of Ni3S2 nanosheets toward HER. Qin and co-worker [28] prepared P doped Ni3S2 nanosheets, which tunes the electronic structure of Ni3S2 and effectively enhances HER activity. Moreover, Qin et al. [29] demonstrated that the overall electronic conductivity and stability for Ni3S2 nanoparticles grown on nickel foam is efficiently improved by incorporating Co and Cu, thus permanently enhancing OER performance of Ni3S2. Even so, it is extremely challenging to systematically screen the novel bifunctional catalysts with superior catalytic activity for HER and OER in experiments, due to expensive raw materials, time-consuming and uncontrollable experimental conditions. Fortunately, multitudinous reports have shown that first principle calculation can as serve as a powerful prediction method to screen the promising bifunctional electrocatalysts at atomic scale by calculating the adsorption interactions between intermediates and substrate as well as reaction overpotentials. To best our knowledge, the systematic theoretical study on the catalytic activity of Ni3S2-based electrocatalysts for overall water splitting has not been reported up to now. Inspired by the above considerations, with the aim of obtaining the highly efficient bifunctional catalysts, we systematically investigated the HER/OER performances of Ni3S2 doped by ten kinds of transition metal atoms (Mn, Fe, Co, Cu, Mo, Ru, Pd, Rh, Ir and Pt) using first-principles calculations. Here, the structural stability of TM-Ni3S2, Gibbs free-energy change for H adsorption ( Δ G H * ), the energy barrier for water dissociation, potential determining step (PDS) and reaction overpotentials for OER were comprehensively explored. Our results indicate that, among all designed candidates, Mn-Ni3S2, Fe-Ni3S2 and Ru-Ni3S2 exhibit excellent OER performance with the much lower theoretical overpotentials of 0.29, 0.29 and 0.33 V, respectively, and high HER activity coupled with the low overpotentials of 0.02, 0.11, and 0.01 V, respectively, which is comparable to or even outperform the well-developed noble catalysts. Our work may provide theoretical guidance to the design of the advanced bifunctional catalysts and help to design excellent Ni3S2-based catalysts for overall water splitting. Method and computational details The Vienna ab-into simulation package(VASP) [30, 31] code based on the density functional theory (DFT) was employed to realize structural optimization and static self-consistent calculations. The electron exchange-correlation was described by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) in the form of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [32]. The projector-augmented-wave (PAW) [33, 34] potentials were adopted to describe the electron-ion interactions. For all the structural relaxations, long-range van der Waals interactions were corrected by DFT-D3 [35] functional. The plane-waves employed for expanding the Kohn-Sham electron wave-functions have an energy cutoff of 500 eV. The convergence tolerances for energy and force were set to be 10−5 eV and 0.02 eV/ Å, respectively. In this work, a 2 × 2 × 1 supercell of (001) surface with 6 atom layers containing 40 atoms was constructed as Ni3S2 substrate, since it has been experimentally observed to be an active surface for water splitting [36]. The reciprocal space was sampled with a 3 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst-pack mesh for Ni3S2 surface. In addition, a vacuum region up to 15 Å was employed in the z-direction to avoid the interaction between two neighboring images. During geometry optimization, the undermost 20 atoms of the slab (bottom three layer) are kept frozen while the three topmost layers are allowed to relax to simulate the surface. The HER performance is assessed via the Gibbs free energy of H adsorption ( Δ G H * ), which is defined by the following expression: (1) Δ G H * = Δ E H * + Δ E Z P E − T Δ S H where Δ E H * is the hydrogen adsorption energy and obtained by Δ E H * = E H * − E − 1 / 2 E H 2 , in which E H * and E represent the total energy of slab model with and without the adsorbed H atom, respectively, and E H 2 denotes the energy of a H2 molecule in the gas phase. Δ E ZPE and Δ S H denote the differences in zero-point energy and entropy between the adsorbed state and gaseous state of hydrogen, respectively. T is temperature and T = 298.15 K in this work. The theoretical exchange current (i 0) can be evaluated according to Nørskov's assumption [37], as shown below: (2) i 0 = − e k 0 1 + exp ( | Δ G H * | / K B T ) where k 0 is rate constant, which contains all factors related to solvent recombination when protons transfer to catalyst surface. Here, it was assumed to be 1 for illustrative purpose in our computations. As is generally reported in experiments, topical OER process occurring at the anode of water splitting in acidic condition, involves four elementary oxidation steps, which can be described as follows: (3) * + H 2 O ( l ) → * OH + H + + e − (4) * OH → * O + H + + e − (5) * O + H 2 O ( l ) → * OOH + H + + e − (6) * OOH → * + O 2 ( g ) + H + + e − here, g and l stand for the gas and liquid phases, respectively. * denotes the activity site on the substrate surface, *O, *OH and *OOH represent the oxygenated groups. It is well established that the Gibbs reaction free energy ( Δ G ) is an important descriptor for OER process, which is obtained by the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model [38] and defined as: (7) Δ G = Δ E + Δ ZPE − T Δ S + Δ G pH + Δ G U where Δ E is the reaction energy obtained from DFT calculations. Δ ZPE and Δ S correspond to the change in zero-point energy and entropy at room temperature (T=298.15 K), respectively, which are calculated by frequency analysis. Δ G pH is free energy change caused by pH, which can be assessed by Δ G pH = K B T × pH × ln 10 , while the last tem Δ G U refers to the free energy contribution with respect to the electrode potential U and the number of electrons transferred n e , which can be determined as Δ G U = − n e U . According to Nørskov's assumption [39], the OER overpotential ( η OER ) in acidic environment is determined by the maximum Δ G of four steps, as computed by: (8) η OER = max { Δ G 1 , Δ G 2 , Δ G 3 , Δ G 4 } / e − 1 . 23 V Moreover, to reveal the role of the different TM centers, the d-band center ( ε d ) was calculated as follows: (9) ε d = ∫ − ∞ E f ε ρ d d ε ∫ − ∞ E f ρ d d ε where E f represents the Fermi level, ρ d denotes the density of states projected onto a single TM atom d orbital and ε is the energy width of the d orbital. Results and discussion Our obtained lattice constant of Ni3S2 bulk is 4.04 Å, and the optimized bond lengths of Ni-S and Ni-Ni are about 2.27 Å and 2.52 Å, respectively, all of which agree well with the experimental data [40]. By cleaving the relaxed Ni3S2 bulk, we constructed three low-index (001) surfaces with different terminations (termination1, termination2 and termination3) and calculated their surface energies (γ) to evaluate the structural stability. The surface energy (γ), is usually calculated by the energy required to split the crystal into two parts along a plane. Here, the surface energy was measured by the excess energy of the surface with respect to the bulk and can be defined as follows [19, 41, 42]: (10) γ = E slab − n E bulk A − E slab unrelaxed − n E bulk 2 A where E slab and E slab unrelaxed are the total energies of relaxed slab and unrelaxed slab, respectively. n denotes the number of Ni3S2 units in slab. E bulk represents the energy of a bulk Ni3S2 formula unit and A is the cross sectional area of the slab. The smaller surface energy means the higher structural stability. As shown in Fig. 1 (a), the relative stability trend of Ni3S2 (001) slab was in the order of termination1 (γ=1.14 J/m2) > termination3 (γ=1.83 J/m2) > termination2 (γ=2.32 J/m2). Obviously, (001) surface with termination1 possessing the smallest value of γ, is the most stable slab model. Therefore, the (001) slab with termination1 is employed to explore the following catalytic activity. The thermodynamic stability of catalysts plays an important role in catalytic activity and unfavorable binding of TM atoms on substrate usually leads to the loss of catalytic performance. Therefore, we first evaluated the stability of TM-Ni3S2 substrate (TM= Mn, Fe, Co, Cu, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir and Pt). For TM doped Ni3S2 substrate, two distinct doping sites were taken into account, i.e., Ni vacancy in the first layer and second layer of the defective Ni3S2 substrate, as depicted in Fig. 1(b). Here, to assess the structural stability of TM-Ni3S2, we first calculated the vacancy formation energy ( E f ) of these two defects by E f = E v − E p + μ N i , in which E v and E p represent the total energy of Ni3S2 with and without vacancy, respectively. μ N i is the chemical potential of Ni atom. The calculated E f values for Ni vacancy in the first layer and second layer are 0.06 and 0.97 eV, respectively. Generally, smaller E f value indicates that higher possibility of vacancy formation. Comparing the E f values of BP with B vacancy (1.66 eV) [43], MoS2 with S vacancy (5.85 eV) [44], graphene with C vacancy (7.69 eV) [45], it is evident that the E f values for Ni3S2 with Ni vacancy is much smaller than those, indicating Ni3S2 exhibits greater possibility to form Ni vacancy. Following, we calculated the binding energy ( E b ) of TM-Ni3S2 candidates, which is described as: E b = E TM , V − E V − E TM , in which E TM , E TM , V and E V correspond to the energies of the isolated TM atom, the defective Ni3S2 substrate doped with and without TM atom, respectively. The lower binding energy corresponds to the higher thermodynamic stability. As displayed in Fig. 1(c), the results show that the E b values of Ni3S2 with TM replacing the Ni atom of second layer are lower than that of TM occupying the Ni vacancy of the first layer, suggesting that TM atom prefers to occupy Ni vacancy in the second layer of Ni3S2(001). Herein, due to the higher thermodynamic stability, the following study on catalytic activity mainly focus on the Ni3S2 doped with TM in the second layer. As is well known, the HER catalytic efficiency can be estimated by the Gibbs free-energy change of the adsorbed H* ( Δ G H * ). A larger positive Δ G H * value suggests that the massive energy needs to be injected in the process of H adsorption on the catalysts surface, while a more negative value indicates that H adsorbed on the catalyst surface is difficult to release, thus inhibiting HER activity. Hence, the Δ G H * value of an ideal catalyst should be around zero to realize the balance of H adsorption and desorption. For comparison, we first examined three possible adsorption sites of H atom for determining the HER activity of pristine Ni3S2 matrix, involving the outermost Ni site, S site and Ni-Ni bridge site. The optimized geometries of adsorption configuration and the corresponding Δ G H * are illustrated in Fig.S1(a). The Ni-Ni site is found to have a smallest Δ G H * value (0.50 eV) than the Ni site (0.67 eV) and S site (1.18 eV), indicating Ni-Ni site is more catalytically active and mainly responsible for the HER, which is consistent with the previous result [19]. For TM-Ni3S2, four possible Ni active sites, three S sites and the active TM sites have been considered, as presented in Fig.S2. The Δ G H * values of TM-Ni3S2 was portrayed in Fig. 2 (a), meanwhile the relaxed configurations of the most stable adsorption model were shown in Fig.S3. Obviously, the results reveal that, in the case of Cu-Ni3S2 and Pd-Ni3S2, the Ni atoms exhibit stronger active for H atom, while the TM atoms are active sites for other TM-Ni3S2 candidates. More importantly, the HER catalytic performances of all the candidates, except Cu-Ni3S2, have been efficiently improved. The Δ G H * values of TM-Ni3S2 are characterized as being between -0.15 and 0.51 eV. Note that Ru-Ni3S2 sample shows the highest HER catalytic activity and the HER catalytic activity of Ni3S2 matrix has significantly improved with the Δ G H * values reduced from 0.50 to -0.01 eV after doping Ru atom. Overall, the HER catalytic performances for three best candidates follow the order of Ru-Ni3S2 (-0.01 eV) > Mn-Ni3S2 (0.02 eV) > Fe-Ni3S2 (0.11 eV), which are comparable to or even outperform than the current prevailing Pt-based catalysts (0.09 eV). However, Cu-Ni3S2 is eliminated due to the unimproved HER performance compared with Ni3S2. Meanwhile, to intuitively represent and quantitatively evaluate the HER catalytic activity of TM-Ni3S2, we established the volcano curve, namely, the relationship between the theoretical exchange current density (i 0) and the adsorption free energy ( Δ G H * ), as plotted in Fig. 2(b). Note that, Mo-Ni3S2, with the relatively strong bonding strength to H atom, lies on the left branch of volcano map. By contrary, the remaining candidates are related to the weak adsorption with H atom, locating on the right-hand side of volcano and showing the relatively low exchange currents, especially Pt-Ni3S2, Pd-Ni3S2 and Cu-Ni3S2. Moreover, the closer the exchange current is to the optimal value (the top of volcano plot), the higher the catalytic activity. Notably, Ru-Ni3S2 and Mn-Ni3S2 are located in the peak of volcano plot, demonstrating the optimal HER catalytic performance, and they yield the significantly low Δ G H * values of -0.01 eV and 0.02 eV, respectively, which surpass the noble Pt-based catalysts. Most importantly, the energy barrier for H2O dissociation plays a vital role in alkaline media and a lower energy barrier for H2O dissociation is a prerequisite to initiate the alkaline HER. Therefore, we calculated the energy barriers for H2O dissociation on Ni3S2 and TM-Ni3S2 surfaces, as shown in Fig.S4. First, we can find that the difference between their H2O adsorption is very small. However, the energy barrier of H2O dissociation shows significantly difference. Obviously, the pristine Ni3S2 exhibits a relatively high energy barrier for H2O dissociation (1.45 eV), indicating sluggish kinetics. Compared with the pure Ni3S2 surface, Cu-Ni3S2 presents a slightly higher energy barrier of 1.60 eV and Pd-Ni3S2 shows a similar energy barrier of 1.44 eV. For other TM-Ni3S2, as we expected, the energy barrier for H2O dissociation significantly decreased, suggesting that doping TM (except Cu and Pd) make it quite convenient for H2O dissociation on Ni3S2 surface. Based on the above results, Cu-Ni3S2 and Pd-Ni3S2 were excluded due to the unimproved hydrogen adsorption and H2O dissociation. Overall, these results demonstrate that metal dopants facilitate the H2O dissociation and optimize hydrogen adsorption, which contributes to faster kinetics upon the first stage of HER process and improves the HER activity of Ni3S2. Apart from HER activity, the OER activity of TM-Ni3S2 candidates was also investigated, and their four-electron reaction free energy profiles are plotted in Fig. 3 , in which the maximum reaction free energy (the potential limiting step) is highlighted in red line and the ideal electrocatalyst is described by the pink step. Meanwhile, the Gibbs free energies of oxygenated intermediates and the optimized intermediates for TM-Ni3S2 sample are summarized in Table S2 and Fig.S3, respectively. Here, to have a comparison, the OER activity of pristine Ni3S2 was first calculated (Fig.S1), yielding a overpotential of 0.68 V, which is agreement with the previous result [19]. Regarding TM-Ni3S2, the considered adsorption sites for *OH, O* and *OOH intermediates are same as the *H mentioned above (Fig.S2). From Fig.S3, we can find that for all the candidates, both *OH and *OOH favor the Ni2 sites on the surface of TM-Ni3S2, while the most favorable sites for *O correspond to the bridge site between Ni and S. As shown in Fig. 3, for all candidates, the second step or third step corresponds to the maximum Gibbs free energy difference, which is mainly attributed to the relatively weak *O binding or *OOH binding on catalysts. Moreover, at the equilibrium potential of 1.23 V, although the first and the forth step turn out to be downhill, the second and third step are still endothermic, with the relatively high energy barrier. In case of Mn-Ni3S2 and Fe-Ni3S2, the satisfactory catalytic activity was obtained, both with the lowest overpotential of 0.29 V. Beyond that, their free energy diagrams at U=0 V are even comparable to the ideal catalyst. Moreover, we found that, for Mo-Ni3S2, Ru-Ni3S2 and Pd-Ni3S2, the third step, where an adsorbed *O groups react with a H2O molecule to form an *OOH specie, is the limiting step, and the corresponding maximum Gibbs free energy change are 2.06, 1.56 and 1.70 eV, respectively. For the remaining TM-Ni3S2, the second reaction step corresponding to the dissociation of adsorbed *OH into *O species, becomes the most demanding step. Overall, the calculated overpotentials are 0.29, 0.29, 0.37, 0.41, 0.83, 0.33, 0.33, 0.47, 0.36 and 0.35 V for TM=Mn, Fe, Co, Cu, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir and Pt, respectively. Apparently, except Mo-Ni3S2, the OER overpotentials of other systems decrease significantly, indicating that OER activity of Ni3S2 can be efficiently improved by doping heteroatom. Taken together, Mo-Ni3S2 is ruled out due to the poor OER performance compared with Ni3S2. Moreover, Mn-Ni3S2 and Fe-Ni3S2 exhibit the best OER activity, which is not only significantly superior to the pristine Ni3S2, but also comparable to or even better than many catalysts reported at present, such as IrN4@G [46], NiIT monolayer [47], Cr-COFs [48], Ni/g-CN [49]. As known, the binding strength between adsorption intermediates and catalyst is of vital importance to OER electrochemical activity. Too weak adsorption can't offer sufficient power for catalytic reaction, while the strong binging will seriously hinder catalytic reaction by blocking substrate surface, resulting in the poor catalytic activity. Therefore, to obtain better OER catalytic efficiency, the key is to control the adsorption strength of reaction intermediates neither too strong nor too weak. Many studies suggest that volcano plots have unique advantageous in describing OER activity and screening highly efficient OER catalysts. The lower overpotential means the higher catalytic efficiency, that is to say, the peak of volcano map corresponds to the best candidate. Herein, we derived activity volcano plots by adopting OER overpotentials as a function of Δ G * O − Δ G * OH , as shown in Fig. 4 . It also can be observed that the optimum Δ G * O − Δ G * OH is about 1.52 eV. Below this optimum value, O* binding on surface is relatively strong, and OER overpotential decreases with the increase of Δ G * O − Δ G * OH , which is dominated by the formation of OOH*. In contrast, when Δ G * O − Δ G * OH > 1.52 eV, overpotential increases with the increase of Δ G * O − Δ G * OH , which is limited by the second reaction step. Regarding Ni3S2 slab, the relatively strong *O binding makes it deviates away from the top of OER activity map, resulting in the formation of OOH* from O* being the rate determining step. Moreover, most candidates are located in the right side of volcano curve, which is mainly ascribed to the relatively weak *O bonding strengths. Only Pd-Ni3S2 and Mo-Ni3S2 occupy in the left branch, indicating that *OH binding on catalyst surface is relatively weak. Impressively, Fe-Ni3S2 and Mn-Ni3S2 fall in the peak zone and possess the optimal OER catalytic performance, which can compete with and even outperform the currently commercial catalysts IrO2/RuO2 (0.55/0.42 V) [39, 50]. Telling from the Eqs.(3-7), it can be seen that the OER catalytic activity is actually determined by the Gibbs free energies of different reaction species, i.e., Δ G * OH , Δ G * O and Δ G * OOH . However, the whole OER reaction can be simplified by establishing the adsorption strength relationship of the oxygenated intermediates. Hence, the scaling relationship between Δ G * OOH and Δ G * OH was investigated, as plotted in Fig. 5 , where the red line corresponds to the scaling fitting between Δ G * OOH and Δ G * OH , and their relations can be represented as: Δ G * OOH = 1 . 10 Δ G * OH + 2 . 95 . Apparently, Δ G * OOH and Δ G * OH display an excellent linear relationship with a relatively high coefficient determination (R2=0.90). Beyond that, two prominent deviations of ±0.02 eV and ±0.04 eV from the fitted line are also plotted in Fig. 5, as highlighted by the yellow and pink regions, respectively. We noticed that all the candidates are perfectly distributed in pink zone, indicating that the defined deviation is reasonable and matches well with our designed catalysts. According to the above linear relationship between Δ G * OOH and Δ G * OH , the free energy change of four steps ( Δ G i ) can be described as: (11) Δ G 1 = Δ G * OH (12) Δ G 2 = Δ G O * − Δ G * OH (13) Δ G 3 = Δ G * OOH − Δ G * O = ( 1 . 10 Δ G * OH + 2 . 95 ) − Δ G 1 − Δ G 2 (14) Δ G 4 = 4 . 92 − Δ G * OOH = 4 . 92 − ( 1 . 10 Δ G * OH + 2 . 95 ) From the above Eqs.(11-14), we notice that, based on two independent variables, i.e., Δ G * OH and Δ G O * − Δ G * OH , the change of reaction free energies for TM-Ni3S2 can be obtained. Following the above, the color-filled contour map of the OER limiting overpotential was plotted to evaluate the OER activity of TM-Ni3S2, as shown in Fig. 6 . Obviously, as indicated by yellow line, the 2D activity volcano plot was classified into four regions by reaction free energy changes, which corresponds to different potential determining step (PDS). As indicated in the dark blue part of Fig. 6, the minimum overpotential was predicted to be only 0.27 V under the premise of Δ G 2 = Δ G 3 = Δ G 4 . Most prominently, all candidates are dispersed in PDS2 and PDS3, which demonstrates that the first H2O→*OH and the forth *OOH→O2 reaction steps can easily occur on the whole OER reaction. Firstly, focusing on the pristine Ni3S2, the *O binding strength is stronger than *OOH binding, resulting in the relatively poor OER performance with a overpotential of 0.68 V and the generation of *OOH species being PDS. Additionally, Mo-Ni3S2 deviates obviously from the optimal activity region than Ni3S2, which is not suitable as the promising candidate for OER. Moreover, for most candidates, such as Rh-Ni3S2, Cu-Ni3S2, Ir-Ni3S2, Co-Ni3S2 and Pt-Ni3S2, the PDS for OER is attributed to *OH→*O reaction process, which is intimately tied to the weak *O adsorption with respect to *OH adsorption. Particularly, regarding Mn-Ni3S2, Fe-Ni3S2 and Ru-Ni3S2, they lie in the boundary line between PDS2 and PDS3 owing to the small difference between Δ G 2 and Δ G 3 , which are very close to the peak of volcano plot, resulting in the outstanding activity with the OER overpotentials of 0.29, 0.29 and 0.33V, respectively. Moreover, Rh-Ni3S, producing the same overpotential as Ru-Ni3S2, 0.33 V, also attracted our attention. Taken together, the rate-limiting steps predicted by the 2D activity volcano plot are in well agreement with the results of Gibbs free energy diagram. Insight into the electronic properties of catalysts can guide us to find the physical origin of catalytic activity. As known, d band center( ε d ) has been widely used as an effective descriptor for binding strength between adsorbate and catalytic surface. Hence, we calculated the ε d of all the TM-Ni3S2 candidates from the corresponding PDOS, as portrayed in Fig. 7 . It is obvious that all the candidates show the metallic characteristics, which demonstrates that excellent conductivity can provide a prerequisite for rapid electron transfer in the electrochemical process. Moreover, the deeper d-band center and larger d electrons generally lead to the weaker binding between intermediates and catalytic surface. From Fig. 7, a typical characteristic can be observed that with the increased d-electron occupation, ε d shows a deeper energy level with respect to the Fermi level, for example, Mn (-0.59) > Fe (-1.16) > Co (-1.17) > Cu (-2.95); Mo (-0.27) > Ru (-1.50) > Rh (-1.60) > Pd (-2.76); Ir (-2.51) > Pt (-2.94). In addition, for the TMs in the same row of the periodic table, except for Pd, a more negative d-band center results in weaker O* binding on TM-Ni3S2 (Fig.S6), which is accordance with the above description, allowing us to optimize the binding energy to an ideal value for the OER by simply tuning TM atoms doped into Ni3S2. When d-band center is in a certain range, the favorable bonding strength between intermediate and catalyst is conducive to the relatively high catalytic activity. The overpotentials of HER and OER on TM-Ni3S2 are summarized in Fig. 8 . Remarkably, Cu-Ni3S2 and Mo-Ni3S2 are excluded due to the unimproved HER and OER activity, respectively. Beyond that, Pd-Ni3S2 is also eliminated because of the unimproved energy barrier for H2O dissociation. Among all the candidates, Ru-Ni3S2 and Mn-Ni3S2 exhibit the extraordinary HER activity with the overpotentilas of 0.01 and 0.02 V, respectively, followed by Fe-Ni3S2 (0.11 V). In addition, the best OER catalysts are Mn-Ni3S2 and Fe-Ni3S2 with the overpotentials of 0.29 V, followed by Ru-Ni3S2 (0.33 V) and Rh-Ni3S2 (0.33 V). Overall, Mn-Ni3S2, Fe-Ni3S2 and Ru-Ni3S2 can serve as the highly promising bifunctional catalysts for overall water splitting. Conclusions In summary, we designed a series of promising TM-Ni3S2 bifunctional catalysts for overall water splitting by first-principles calculations. Our results reveal that the catalytic activity of Ni3S2 for HER/OER can be efficiently tuned by doping TM atoms. More importantly, Ru-Ni3S2 exhibits the best catalytic activity toward HER, followed by Mn-Ni3S2 and Fe-Ni3S2. Meanwhile, these three catalysts also possess remarkable OER performances, being capable of driving HER/OER with the extremely low overpotentials of 0.02/0.29, 0.11/0.29 and 0.01/0.33 V for Mn-Ni3S2, Fe-Ni3S2 and Ru-Ni3S2, respectively, which is significantly superior to the reported catalysts, especially the traditional precious-metal-based catalysts. Furthermore, by plotting 2D volcano pattern, we determined the optimal activity condition of TM-Ni3S2 candidates, where the corresponding limiting overpotential is 0.27 V. Most importantly, the OER activity origin was revealed by d-band center. Our findings may open up new opportunities and bring about new insights into the rational design of highly efficient Ni3S2-based electrocatalysts for water splitting. coredata.dc:description: Exploring stable, inexpensive and highly active bifunctional electrocatalyst for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a long-desired topic in the area of sustainable and renewable energy sources. Herein, ten kinds of transition metal (TM = Mn, Fe, Co, Cu, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir and Pt) were doped in Ni3S2 matrix to design TM-Ni3S2 candidates, and their catalytic activities for overall water splitting were systematically explored based on density functional theory. Our results demonstrated that doping TM atoms is an effective tactic to boost the catalytic activity of Ni3S2 matrix. Among these candidates, Mn-Ni3S2, Fe-Ni3S2, and Ru-Ni3S2 exhibit the outstanding catalytic activity for water splitting, with the much lower overpotentials being just 0.02/0.29 V, 0.11/0.29 V and 0.01/0.33 V for HER/OER, respectively, which are equivalent to or even superior to the prevailing bifunctional catalysts. Particularly, d-band center was employed to reveal the origin of OER activity. Our findings may open up new routes for the design of advanced Ni3S2-based catalysts for water splitting and realize the wide-range applications of Ni3S2-based catalysts in fields of clean and renewable energy.
coredata.dc:title: Transition metal atom doped Ni3S2 as efficient bifunctional electrocatalysts for overall water splitting: Design strategy from DFT studies
